revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian | name = Cardis Cardell Willis | image = CardellWillis.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = Willis on stage before a comeback on a heckler | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date|1937|4|20|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Forest, Mississippi]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|2|10|1937|4|20}} | death_place = [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], [[United States|U.S.]] | medium = [[Stand-up comedy]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | active = c1950s–1990s | genre = [[Satire]], [[Observational comedy]], [[Black comedy]], [[Improvisational comedy]], Character comedy | subject = [[race relations]], [[American politics]], [[African-American culture]], [[human sexuality]], [[self-deprecation]], [[everyday life]], [[family]] | influences = [[Jack Benny]], [[George Burns]], [[Redd Foxx]], [[Bill Cosby]], [[Richard Pryor]], [[Lenny Bruce]], [[Rodney Dangerfield]], and [[Mort Sahl]] | influenced = [[Will Durst]], Dobie Maxwell, Richard Halasz, Chris Barnes | notable_work= | signature = | website = | footnotes = | emmyawards = }}
'''Cardis Cardell Willis''', better known as Cardell Willis, and often billed as C. Cardell Willis, was an influential Milwaukee comic. He was locally known mostly in the 1970s, 1980's, and 1990's. He went by the name Cardell socially and professionally, but used his formal name legally.
Willis was born in 1937 either on April 20, or August 3. The discrepancy is due to the remoteness of his hometown of [[Forest, Mississippi|Forest]], Mississippi, and that births had to reported in the capital of [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]] at the time.
He was mentor to [[Will Durst]] before his eventual fame in San Francisco, and [http://dobiemaxwell.com/ Dobie Maxwell], as well as Richard Halasz, and Chris Barnes, all of whom are natives to [[Milwaukee]].
He eventually developed [[Alzheimers]] which robbed him of his ability to tell the storied jokes he was known for. He died on February 10, 2007 in a group home at age 69 after suffering two [[Stroke|strokes.]] He was buried at Graceland Cemetery in Milwaukee.
A tribute show occurred to honor Willis' contributions, and generosity to his peers, and community. The [[Master of Ceremonies|MC]] was Dobie Maxwell, who called Willis his [[Father#Fatherhood defined by contact level with child|Comedy Father.]] The tribute show was donation supported and the remaining proceeds were given to the [[Boy Scouts of America]], in which Willis was a Scoutmaster and had received the [[Silver Beaver Award]].
According to onmilwaukee.com, [[Tom Barrett (Wisconsin politician)|Mayor Barrett]] designated April 22, 2012, as Cardell Willis Day.
== References == *[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_multi=MWSB|PKPB&p_product=MSNP&p_theme=msnp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=cardell%20willis%20AND%20date()&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(cardell%20willis)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no Archives of Willis from jsonline.com] *[https://archive.is/20130127015620/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=565657 Obituary from Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel] *[https://archive.is/20070419215630/http://www.chicagostylestandups.com/dobie/index.php?yy=2007&mm=2&dd=12 Blog on Chicago Standups from Dobie Maxwell] *[http://www.onmilwaukee.com/myOMC/blog/show/311 Dobie Maxwell's reaction to Willis' death] *{{YouTube|EdKxDhlTDCU|MKE Funny interviews of Willis' family and fellow comedians}} *[http://onmilwaukee.com/ent/articles/cardtrib2012.html Article on onmilwaukee.com discussing tribute show]
